author: Trevdo
body: I did the same thing. I started investing in 2016 going all Canadian cannabis (ACB, WEED, APH). In 2019 I pulled out 85% of my Cannabis and threw it into XEQT. The remaining 15% I held, and well, I think you guys can figure out what happened there. For people that have a fairly small portfolio (let’s say 10-20-% of yearly earnings) I would go 50% XEQT and 50% individual stocks. If you think you can really beat XEQT, try your best, but 8/10 times, you won’t.

author: CannaVestments
body:
Fair enough- good points. I'd point out a few things though:

1) Market share for the top LPs (canopy, Aph, acb, Tilray) has been on a multi-year downward trend as Canada continues to license new operators and small players continue to take share. Not saying that continues forever but going to be a challenge. The legacy Aphria business had more cannabis revenue 1 year ago in Q4 2020 than this most recent report for example when the market expanded significantly in that time. Buying their way to $1B seems more likely 

2) 25% of all of Europe where there are hundreds of different players seems like a long shot. No doubt in a good position but 1/4 of the entire market is asking a lot. There are quite a few scaled, private companies targeting the export market to Europe 

3) All good 

4) I don't think it'll be any of the largest players. Cura and GTI are already larger by market cap and Trul/verano/cresco will continue to catch up. My point is mainly that they are essentially buying their way to $4B with this approach, meaning shareholders are getting diluted to fund it. It's not quite the same as organic growth that actually raises the share price 

Plausible sure, but unlikely imo. Would need to execute close to perfect at every aspect across the board

author: NextTrillion
body: I remember that well. I wanted to get in, but the SP ran on me. I thought it would go lower. But I vowed to learn from that, and that def. helped me really average down on APH during the short report. I’ve since come to really appreciate these bears.

author: wet_tree
body:
It’s kind of a double edge sword. When they merged with tlry they became a traders favorite. 

In that same vein a lot of them might not be “conviction” holders and therefore not voting. 

I have to say that the mmen optics and the names attached that call back to dark days for $aph could also be a tough sell. 

Exciting times.

author: skinniks
body: Look at how Aph and Tilray deal was structured.  It's not as simplistic as buying out Trul.  You buy off the insiders and give everyone else proportionate ownership in the combined entity.  I'm not sure about other MSO's but I feel pretty strongly that the end game for Kim and friends is to cash out.  They feel like the company most likely to pull a MedReleaf.

author: bananastock
body:
Love the lack of comments here. Volume is almost as low as it will go IMO.

HEXO deal with redecan closed. is their deal with 48 north done too?
CEO said they have a food partner in the USA, a fortune 200 company who they haven't disclosed yet. I'm curious to see who it is.

Also, if y'all we'rent paying attention, the mounting speculation of the 100M investor in Aphria is probably Michael Serruya given his 100M investment in MedMen and simultaneous deal with Tilray. He was also involved as an investor in LHS which Ayr now owns and was an early investor in APH when Vic was ceo....during the short attack.

Crazy world we live in. Enjoy the ride, Folkes.

author: GraysonMA
body:
TL;DR
For your ETF’s add TMF, LLY, PG, and VZ 

Buy **low-correlation assets**  to complement your specific portfolio. These will reduce how wildly your portfolio swings up and down and can actually improve your gains with proper rebalancing. I use [portfoliovisualizer.com](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=TQQQ+SPXL+TMF+LLY+KO+VZ+PG+NVDA+UNH+ISRG+GOOG+APPS+AMD+AAPL+FB+AVGO+AMZN+GE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36) to check correlations. I added the suggestions from the other comments for tickers more than 2 years old. You can run this tool on any companies you like to see which ones are the best fit. Since you are already using leveraged ETFs, I would recommend adding TMF (at least until bond yields start rising again). For individual stocks, I recommend LLY, PG, VZ, or any mega cap company that has less than .5 correlation to both of your ETFs.

author: Violet604
body:
I’m the same, like to buy growth tech stocks with dividends during corrections. Picked up Broadcom under $170 when it was yielding around 8%.

Although when I look at my sister in laws portfolio, and see her dad bough her Nutrien stock when it was $14 yielding 4%, and now it’s in the $70’s (cdn) yielding over 3%. When I did the math, I think her yield on cost was around 14%!

So if you look into some of those core holding companies with solid long term dividend growths, it’s like putting your money in the bank, and each year they increase the interest they pay you. But this way you get some capital appreciation too.

author: pandatears420
body:
For reasons similar to those in the TSM thread, I like Broadcom Inc. (AVGO). Currently the market cap is just under $200 billion. 

Their business as grown significantly over the last 2 years and has been showing reliable growth for years before. 

And I like the stock because in addition to growth I see a nice dividend.

author: solscend
body: My favorite four are nvda adbe shop avgo (broadcom), super solid group

author: SupremeStrabotomy
body:
it really seems more like an “everything that could possibly have turned this company around” sale

from my understanding they are letting go of anything and everything related to streaming services, eg. when the sold off TimeWarner assets to Discovery and now Crunchyroll. 

When they asked the CEO about it he said that it was in order to focus more on internet connectivity, aka 5G and improving their broadband capability to position themselves as actual competition for $VZ, $AVGO and $TMUS, who basically already dominate the sector.

author: Celetus

Many of these companies have significant moats. I prefer to have several stocks across the spectrum of the semconductor supply chain with my picks being among those listed below:

Semconductor Equipment: AMAT, LCRX, ASML, KLAC, STM

Foundries: TSM (maybe UMC)

Fabless: AMD, Nvidia, Qualcomm, Broadcom

Memory/Logic chips: Micron, Samsung, Intel

&#x200B;

Others worth mentioning: MRVL, ON, AOSL, SIMO.

author: t_per

author: mistermc90
body:
Hi

As i am invested and did my DD and DCF on GEO:

There are 2 major risks:

A) loss of contracts with us government agencies which could lead up to 50% drop in rev/op CF/profits

-> i did a sensitivity analysis and modeled out drops until - 50% overall after looking at all of their facilities
-> Conclusion: the margin of safety even in case of a partial loss of contracts is huge (IRR north of 20% for 10 y holding)

B) refinancing risk: take a closer look at the payment schedule of GEOs debt. 2024 could be crucial as they are in need of hefty refinance by then. Problem is: some bank institutes don't want to finance them because of the bad press.

My take:
A) offers a good margin of safety even if things go south. B) banks want one thing and that is make money. GEO offers strong CF and is likely to be able to repay debt and interest. I believe some institute is going to refinance them.

I hope that helped. I wish you all the best and continue to do your own DD. I am interested in your opinion!

BR,
Chris

author: beepboopaltalt
body: lol in az $175k is non existent. $200-300k is a 1 br apartment that is run down. 300K + is when you start to see decent 1br and 2br, then 400k is a nice 2br/3br apartment/townhome or a shit regular house.

author: grassmunkie
body: All evidence shows this works and is safe after 9 months unless they are faking it.  Yet the management are holding shares tight and have been buying all the way up.  The rest is noise.  I wish I bought this earlier but with only 40 million float, and 3.4 billion market cap in a market where this drug can br doing 45 billion a year in sales, it’s a no brainer.  Dumping as much $$$ as I can into this.

author: tatabusa
body: Yah but investing has to start somewhere lol. Being poor isnt an excuse. If not OP will forever br stuck in a cycle of inflation with no way out

author: AccountingMajorDood
body:
You do realize BR puts their money in literally so many stocks it's impossible to count. The amount of money they put in NKLA is like literally pennies for them. Not any sign of bullish.

Stay tf away from NKLA and move on. Find a different play instead of gambling.

author: badtradesguy
body:
1) thinking long term - only spreads your risk. it has zero effect on whether something will br successful or not.

3,4,5 - Research - as retail traders, we have access to the same information everyone has. This means we have no edge in w.e analysis we have. those privy to this information before hand will have edge. If you are relying on this, your hope is that someone in the future sees the same value you see today.

you will find your dd has a tendency to be more right in a bull market, since everything is going up. 

If you really want to confirm your DD and research ability, then you will have to find those come back stories in bull markets and have a high degree of success. You will also need to be able to identify when a stock will sell off.

However, unless you are getting paid well and this is your sole occupation, its unlikely you will pick up on these, to the success that would confirm your ability.

some people will disagree with the above, but this is my observations after 15 years.

Your best bet in being successful is focusing on risk management.

Your overall portfolio should have an expected return and a plan for a drawdown. Within this portfolio you can have an allocation for riskier plays but a drawdown in these positions should not eclipse your expected annual return.

The real game is holding on to your winnings.

author: necrophrenic
body:
House prices here went up too but still very affordable - this problem still regional.

My fiancee had no issue with house payments on a $25k salary with a kid (3 BR bought for $120k).

Unfortunately a $100k salary isn't shit compared to a $50k salary elsewhere with lower cost of living.

author: fibonacciii
body: Competition is good. Remember when Pubg came out and BR was supposed to kill are traditional FPS? Everyone said CoD would die -- it evolved into a massive ecosystem. The fact of the game is cash is king, and Activision sits on 10B in cash, with no cost of capital to operate. They are a self sustaining entity who understands games, are a business.
